comments.commentBody: Lyin Ryan and Lyin Trump!  These are the Republican "leaders"?

45 minutes for Ryan to flip.
My experience tells me that flips like that happen either because of a bribe or a threat.
We'll see which it is over the next few weeks...

Mr.Ryan lost his courage, integrity and honesty. He was intimidated that he may loose his speakership, he surrendered. Honesty and courage are rare in politicians. He has no shame. We should not blame him only, look at Lindsey Graham, Bobby Jindal, Rick Perry, Marco Rubio etc etc , these Republican leaders are shameless and have no sense of prestige. How these politicians can think to give Trump the nuclear code? It is totally irresponsible and insane. May God save America and the world.
Donald Trump is 100% correct about America and the republican party.  “If these systems are broken, then fix them!”
Funny that the Republicans are now willing to compromise with Trump, but with Obama? Racism runs deep.

Trump, Trump, Trump. NYT, what's up? Two front page articles, and four editorials about Trump. There is no "news", or opinion in this editorial that hasn't already been covered. You certainly don't need to worry about being left, or Democratic leaning this year. Like a tabloid paper you are enamored by the Donald, and dysfunctional Republican party while ignoring the basic rule that there is no such thing as bad press, You're handing the election to Trump by totally ignoring that the Democrats are the only sane party in the race. It's hard to imagine that you find that reality to boring to print. Hope you're not surprised when Trump wins.

Until he loses his magical popularity with the only numerically significant voting base the Republican Party has, working-class whites, Trump holds all the aces, and Ryan knows it. Negotiating with Trump for Ryan is like "negotiating" with Don Vito. Trump's the ones with the offers you can't refuse, not Ryan.

This comment is a bit off topic but one I feel inspired to write.  It's about a young Republican congressman, an Iraq veteran, who's giving interviews on cable news programs who caught my ear; a Republican I actually listened to.  And that's because he's broadminded honest, authentic, apparently wise and rational.  And unlike Ryan and most others on that side of the aisle who put party first regardless the consequences (habitual obstructionism, shutting down government, refusing to hear a qualified supreme court justice nominee and now supporting an idiotic presidential nominee), this model Republican who sees that Trump is dangerous and unqualified, won't bend.  This is what he said, "Leadership is more than populist rhetoric."  Wow.  Out of the mouth of a Republican.  His name is Adam Kinzinger, Republican congressman from Illinois.  So Republicans, in my opinion, if you want to right the train wreck you've created and become, you have someone within your own ranks, right under your collective noses, who can show you the way.

“We will be having additional discussions, but remain confident there’s a great opportunity..."

Translation: obtuseness reigned, meeting a bust, now at an impasse.

Gadzooks but political platitudes become really boring after 40+ years of hearing the same ole phrases used for the same ole reasons said in the same ole way...

Far fromtaking a principled stand against the excesses of Donald Trump, Ryan is proving he is one of the most dishonest, hypocritical, and cynical politicians in America. Like all living Republicans, Ryan did his part to foist the know-nothing Sarah Palin on us. For decades, he zealously championed the atheistic, anti-Christian doctrines of Ayn Rand, only to make a half-hearted effort to distance himself from her philosophy in 2012 when he realized it would undercut his chances of becoming the GOP VP nominee. He rushed into the House visitors gallery in 2014 for a photo-op with the Duck Dynasty patriarch, thereby giving his endorsement to the patriarch's homophobic and racist remarks recently published in a magazine interview.

His Hamlet-like charade over Trump is another transparent exercise in political cynicism. Ryan wants to run for president in 2020, and he realizes too close association with Trump will not go over well with the American electorate. At the same time, he doesn't want to risk his presidential prospects by seriously offending Trump's Republican supporters. Hence, we are subjected to this pathetic charade of the past few days.

To Ryan's other defects of character we can now add cowardice. Where any concern for his country lies in all this escapes me completely.

Speaker Ryan ought to remember that history is watching. He will either be remembered as a man who, after participating in the 2009 inauguration night conspiracy matured to become a statesman with integrity and refused to endorse Donald Trump, or he will be remembered as a craven political hack in the shameful mold of his Senate counterpart, Mitch McConnell.

Both Trump and Ryan are closer than we are made to believe, hypocrisy and rigid ideology part of the package (Ryan's budget is a farce, if analyzed), a republican party adamant in obstructing even basic requirements for a functioning government. They sure are doing a 'heck of a job', by torpedoing sensible reforms and blocking the means (the power of the purse) necessary to guarantee that government will, indeed, fail, and show how right they were all along (glaringly two-faced). Trump's only interest in 'getting along' is  the craving of  the cash cow the G.O.P. can elicit, so to remain competitive. Trump's empty rhetoric will come in the open once he is forced to explain himself, and stop demagoguing the issues, once the debates with Clinton start. His bullying, a sign of weakness really, will be difficult to harness, as he continues to do what he does best, talk about himself and his 'huge' success as a businessman, his bankruptcies and tax evasions notwithstanding. Given that the G.O.P. will most assuredly genuflect to his whims, it is up to a, so far, compliant Press, to show spine and not let Trump get away with 'murder'.

Of course Ryan caved. The Republican party long ago stopped standing *for* anything coherent, and now stands only *against* - specifically, against Obama, but generally, against any kind of social contract or progress. When you don't stand for something, you're pretty easy to push over.
It wasn't always this way. There was a time both parties were comparatively moderate, somewhat left or right of centre, but only the real wacko birds were at the far ends of the bell curve. It is possible to have an intellectually and ethically respectable conservative party; in fact, I'd argue it's vital, as one-party domination never works out well even when it's the party you generally espouse. A 'loyal opposition' is necessary for a healthy body politic, to challenge your assumptions and force you to think. (Which is why Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Antonin Scalia were best friends; that, and being opera buffs.) To fly straight, an eagle needs both left and right wings.
Perhaps the GOP has run its course and must join the Whigs in the crypt of history. Or it must reform, which means repudiating Trump, who has no firm principle except Trump. If the GOP refused to nominate him and forced Trump into a third-party run, I suspect we'd see his supposed power base crumble. I think a lot of people claim to support him just to be trolls, but when push came to shove they'd stick with the established party.

Any money involved in this? I am very concerned that our government is in the final stages of being entirely bought and paid for.  I feel sorry for the children.  Lead in the water? Oh well.  Lousy schools? Oops. Devastating environmental deals? Sure.  Lying car manufacturers? Par for the course.  Lost your house?  You must deserve it.  Can't find a job or live on 7 bucks an hour? You must be lazy.  So, we better round up the immigrants because they ruined everything, right?  I have to stop now for a brief, intense cry.  I am grieving.

Now 68 years of age, I have seen American society navigate some terribly perilous passages: the assassinations in the 1960s of our most inspired leaders, the million agonies of the Vietnam war, the self-indulgence of the youthful counterculture, Nixon-Kissinger's almost casual cruelties in foreign policy, the lawlessness in high places that culminated in Watergate, Dubya's massive and unnecessary intervention in Iraq--plus recessions, inflations, and devaluations.

Still, I never quite despaired of this country with its Constitutional government that was 'created by geniuses so that it could be implemented by idiots.' However, the level of cluelessness that is now waiting in the wings in the person of Donald Trump has me totally flummoxed.

For the first time I genuinely despair of what the future might bring to these fair shores, whose population embodies so much good will and so much active genius. It almost seems that a large percentage of our voting population has unconsciously elevated our most incompetent politicians in order to create a future chaos of Biblical proportions.

Have we really become so hating--and so full of self-hatred? That is the question that all voters will be answering this November. If worse comes to worst, we can at least go down fighting the darkness descending. Please work and vote for human reason. America is still ours for the saving.

Of course, Mr. Ryan "warms up to" Mr. Trump! Raise your hand if you are actually surprised by this development? Even a dead and blind Ray Charles could clearly see that this would happen.

Mr. Ryan is just like the Speaker before him--craven, unable to control his own caucus, and placing his party before the good of the country. Not to mention mendacious. It's been fascinating watching Trump's loudest critics engaging in a contest to see who could roll over the fastest in kissing Trump's ring in the vainglorious hope of snatching a few crumbs of power for themselves. Rubio; Perry; Christie; Ryan...and the list goes on. It's only a matter of time before the man who proudly sought Trump's support in 2012--Mr. Romney--rolls over, too. Not surprising, since Romney was like a weather vane. Now, had this bunch spoken up a lot sooner when Trump started his ill-advised "birther" nonsense, they wouldn't be in the position now of prostrating themselves at his feet.

Now, Ryan is in the position of having to explain how a candidate who is openly embraced by white supremacists is somehow "better than Hillary." Please proceed, Mr. Speaker! Perhaps, instead of repeatedly voting to repeal the ACA, Ryan and his ilk should see if it covers backbone replacement surgery.

It's hard to believe the hype about serious negotiations between Trump and Ryan. Trump has no fixed positions, he doesn't even understand there is a connection between words and the things they represent. How do you negotiate with someone who isn't bound by own promises made a day earlier?

But Trump is instinctively expert at gauging the reaction of his listeners and triangulating his responses. When setting out his opinions, will know just how far to go with Ryan. I imagine that Trump's side of the conversation with Ryan would consist of the usual jello-like meaningless sentence fragments, devoid in this instance of the more objectionable policy specifics like the wall with Mexico. Lots of head nodding and pauses by Ryan. When the 45 minutes set aside for the meeting elapse, there will be smiles and handshakes. Meeting over and a pro forma press release is put out attesting to "progress".

Does that mean that the objectionable policies, like the wall, have been dropped? No.

In the end, everyone knows, including Ryan, that he will sign up to be one of Trump's new apprentices. So will all the other republicans.

The only serious negotiations between Trump and Ryan were to establish the timetable for Ryan to come around to endorsing Trump. He can't endorse right away, he'll look too easy. But it's inevitable. For most republicans, it's all about appearances.

Very  interesting to watch self-styled "principled conservatives" fall in line behind an opportunistic, self-promoting, unprincipled non-conservative. They're all showing their true colors now. The only principle that any are attached to is self advancement regardless of the cost to the country or the public good.
Trump becomes GOP Pres candidate, Ryan as VP. Some time after inauguration Trump in hissy fit resigns; Ryan assumes Presidency.
Donald Trump and Paul Ryan are dancing around each other like jumping spiders.  Why would Paul support Trump if he ever hopes to convince American voters of his sound judgment?

The House is gridlocked! Nothing can get done! The Tea Party blocks Ryan's legislation! Now, of course, the GOP could be more moderate and try and attract some democrats, but that would violate the Hastert Rule.

Yet when the Democrats controlled the house and passed legislation with their overwhelming majority while simultaneously making every concession possible to republicans in the name of cooperation (including passing a health care law modeled on conservative principles), they "rammed it down the throats of the American people."

Another neat trick pulled off by the GOP: infuriate their base while disingenuously claiming that democrats refused to work across he isle (when, in fact, they did try), while simultaneously refusing to pass any legislation if it wouldn't pass with only republican support.

Does GOP hypocrisy know no limits? Will the American public ever pay attention? Given that many democrats (aka BernieBots) consistently sit out the midterms and then complain that democrats are too centrist, the answer is clearly 'no'.

It must have been some meeting.

On the one hand, the devout Catholic Mr. Paul "to help you is to hurt you" Ryan, who's lived on government jobs and government contracts his whole life. On the Other, Mr. Populist Trump, with his failed casinos and sham university, designed to part fools from their money, customers, investors and creditors alike all welcome.

Settle differences? What differences?
In the name of hyper-masculinity, the Republicans are showing the most profound and disgusting ethical weakness. Where is the courage ?

Ryan will eventually embrace Trump, lock, stock, and barrel, as will most Republicans now on the sidelines. Even McCain, who was dissed by Trump in the most profound way, puts party loyalty above all else.  Likewise, when McConnell spoke for the GOP by indicating their highest priority was to unseat Obama, rather than govern or directly address the needs of Americans. It's all about beating the Democrats, end of story. Everything going on now is background noise and posturing, before lining up behind a fraud, a phony, an incompetent, a disaster - by their own words.
This is so much fun!!!!!!  Better than the Kardashians!
